question_details.query: How does the evidence for using acoustic devices to reduce human-wildlife conflict at aquaculture systems compare to their use on fishing gear?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across six studies at aquaculture systems, four studies reported reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions, or fewer harbour seals approaching cages, while two studies found no reductions for harbour seals or common bottlenose dolphins around fin-fish farms [2775]. On fishing gear, six studies focused on human–wildlife conflict reported that five found reduced damage to fish catches and/or nets caused by common bottlenose dolphins and seals, while one found no reduction in damage to swordfish catches by California sea lions [2808]. The evidence base is larger overall for fishing gear (33 studies total on marine mammals, with six addressing conflict outcomes) than for aquaculture systems (six studies total), with mixed outcomes in both contexts [2808, 2775].
summary_statements: Four of six studies at aquaculture systems reported reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals, and South American sea lions.
Four of six studies at aquaculture systems reported fewer harbour seals approaching cages.
Two studies at aquaculture systems found no reductions for harbour seals or common bottlenose dolphins around fin-fish farms.
Out of six studies on fishing gear focused on human-wildlife conflict, five found reduced damage to fish catches and/or nets caused by common bottlenose dolphins and seals.
One study on fishing gear focused on human-wildlife conflict found no reduction in damage to swordfish catches by California sea lions.
The overall evidence base is larger for fishing gear than for aquaculture systems.
The evidence base for fishing gear includes 33 total studies on marine mammals, with six of those studies addressing conflict outcomes.
The evidence base for aquaculture systems includes six total studies.
Outcomes have been mixed in both the aquaculture system and fishing gear contexts.

question_details.query: How does the evidence for using acoustically reflective materials on fishing gear compare to attaching acoustically reflective objects for reducing marine mammal entanglement?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across two actions, evidence differs in strength and outcomes. For attaching acoustically reflective objects, two studies (Timor/Arafura Seas; Gulf of Alaska) found no benefits: metallic bead chains on nets did not reduce dolphin entanglements, and acrylic beads near hooks did not reduce sperm whale depredation on catches [2806]. For using acoustically reflective materials in the gear itself, five studies (Canada, Denmark, Argentina) reported mixed but partly positive results: two of three controlled studies (including two replicated) found fewer harbour porpoise entanglements in nets made with iron-oxide or barium sulfate, while one study found barium sulfate nets did not reduce dolphin entanglements; behavioural studies showed porpoises approached barium sulfate and conventional nets similarly, with fewer echolocation clicks at barium sulfate nets and similar overall echolocation activity at both net types [2807].

question_details.query: What is the evidence for interventions that directly manage individual mammals to boost threatened populations?
What are the potential negative impacts associated with using acoustic deterrent devices for marine mammal conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Studies reported behavioural changes associated with acoustic deterrent devices, including: marine mammals approaching fishing nets or lines less closely, having fewer encounters or interactions with nets, and reduced activity and sightings in surrounding areas when devices were placed on fishing gear (action 2808); dolphins avoiding a boat more frequently when devices were deployed alongside it, killer whales recorded further from a fishing vessel during device use with distances decreasing after first exposure, and reduced surfacing, echolocation, and time spent foraging or socializing by dolphins when devices were used from vessels (action 2815); reduced numbers or activity of seals, porpoises, and dolphins near moored devices, reduced echolocation activity of harbour porpoises with increasing probability of close approaches over 10–11 days, and reductions in seal numbers upstream of devices without reducing overall numbers (action 2816).

question_details.query: What are the most effective interventions for reducing cetacean bycatch in fishing nets, based on evidence from the Atlantic and North Sea?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across the North Atlantic and North Sea, deploying acoustic devices (pingers) on fishing nets and lines has repeatedly reduced cetacean entanglements or collisions, including fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises and other small cetaceans; a controlled study in the North Atlantic also found nets with a complete set of pingers had fewer harbour porpoise entanglements than nets with an incomplete set, and a replicated, controlled study spanning the North Sea and Baltic Sea showed reductions in harbour porpoise entanglement in one fishing area though not the other [2808]. Using acoustically reflective net materials (e.g., iron‑oxide or barium sulfate) has also reduced harbour porpoise entanglements in the North Sea, though another study found barium‑sulfate nets did not reduce dolphin entanglements [2807].

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the success of releasing hand-reared or captive-bred manatees back into the wild in the Americas?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Hand-reared/captive-reared releases: Two replicated studies in Brazil and Florida reported that approximately three-quarters of Antillean manatees and two-thirds of Florida manatees released after captive rearing were known to survive for at least one year, with some individuals surviving for more than seven years [2926]. One replicated study in Brazil found that most captive-reared Antillean manatees released back into the wild reproduced [2926]. However, three studies reported poor outcomes for some captive-reared manatee calves (West Indian and Antillean), including deaths before or after release, returns to captivity, or survival only with supplemental feeding [2926].
- Captive-bred releases: Two studies in Brazil and Florida found that two of three Antillean manatees and two of 14 Florida manatees born in captivity and released into the wild survived for at least one year without further intervention [2933].

question_details.query: How do the outcomes of using catch protection devices on longlines compare to modifying fishing pots for reducing human-wildlife conflict?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Catch and hook protection devices on longlines: Across five studies, one study reported fewer unwanted catches of toothed whales when cage or chain devices were used on hooks (2821). Two of four studies (including controlled and before-and-after designs) found that net sleeves or cage/chain devices on hooks reduced damage to fish catches by sperm whales, killer whales and toothed whales, while the other two studies found that ‘umbrella’ or ‘spider’ devices did not reduce predation or damage by sperm whales or toothed whales (2821). One controlled study found streamer-based catch protection on lines reduced Indo-Pacific bottlenose and spinner dolphin bait predation, but only during the first two trials (2821). Modifying fishing pots and traps: Two controlled studies (one replicated) found that adding steel rods to lobster pots or metal frames to pots reduced the number of Australian sea lion pups or grey and harbour seals entering or becoming trapped (2822). Two controlled studies (one replicated) reported that installing wire grids or steel bars on trap-nets or bag-nets, along with strengthened netting or other access-preventing modifications, reduced damage to salmon catches by seals (2822). One controlled study showed that securing crab pot doors with a bungee cord (one of two methods) reduced common bottlenose dolphin interactions (2822). One controlled study found that wire grids on trap-nets, with strengthened netting, resulted in higher catches of undamaged salmon but not whitefish, likely due to reduced seal predation (2822).

question_details.query: What interventions are available to mitigate the impacts of underwater noise from construction activities like pile driving?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Relevant documented interventions include: using bubble curtains or screens to dampen underwater noise during pile driving; one before-and-after, site comparison study in the North Sea reported smaller decreases in harbour porpoise detections within 15 km compared to sites without these measures [2901]. Reducing hammer energy during pile driving is listed, but no studies were found evaluating its effects [2900]. Using ‘soft start’ procedures to deter mammals is documented; across three studies in the UK, Gabon and Australia, cetaceans more often avoided or moved away during soft starts, short-finned pilot whales initially moved away but remained within 900 m, and migrating humpback whales slowed but did not significantly alter course [2897]. Acoustic deterrent devices to keep mammals away from noisy areas are reported; four studies in Germany, Denmark and Iceland found reduced harbour porpoise activity or sightings at 1–18 km and minke whales moving away with increased speed and straighter paths [2896]. Delaying or ceasing operations when mammals are detected within a specified zone is listed, but no studies were found evaluating its effects [2898]. Modifying vessels to reduce noise disturbance is listed, but no studies were found evaluating its effects [2904]. Limiting, ceasing or prohibiting the use of sonars is listed, but no studies were found evaluating its effects on subtidal benthic invertebrates [2210].

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of education and community engagement programs on human behaviour towards marine mammals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Educational programmes were associated with increased willingness among participants to change their behaviour to support marine conservation, to donate money to marine conservation, and for fishers to cut their nets to save entangled dolphins, based on three before-and-after studies following educational whale-watching tours or an educational exhibition in the USA, Bangladesh, and Peru [2935]. No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of involving local communities in marine or freshwater mammal conservation projects on outcomes, so documented behavioural impacts from community engagement are not available [2936].

question_details.query: What are the benefits and harms of using acoustic devices on fishing gear in coastal waters to protect porpoises?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across 33 studies, using acoustic devices on fishing gear was reported to: (a) reduce harbour porpoise entanglements in several regions and fisheries, including cases where nets equipped with a complete set of devices had fewer porpoise entanglements, though reductions varied by area and gear and were not universal (2808); (b) decrease porpoise approach distance to nets and reduce encounters, activity, and sightings near nets or lines in multiple controlled studies, while some studies found no significant behavioural effect on harbour porpoises (2808).

question_details.query: What is the state of the evidence for actions designed to mitigate the risks of renewable energy infrastructure to marine and freshwater mammals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across identified actions aimed at mitigating risks from renewable energy infrastructure to marine and freshwater mammals, no studies were found evaluating their effectiveness: using real-time automated detection tools to pause or modify operations at renewable energy sites [2749]; modifying the design of underwater turbines [2747]; deploying acoustic devices at renewable energy sites [2748]; and translocating marine and freshwater mammals before the onset of impactful activities [2931].

question_details.query: How does the evidence for modifying fishing pots and traps to exclude mammals compare with installing exclusion or escape devices on fishing nets?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Six studies assessed modifying pots/traps to exclude mammals across the North Sea (UK, Sweden), Indian River Lagoon (USA), Gulf of Finland, Bothnian Sea, Indian Ocean (Australia), and Baltic Sea; two controlled studies (one replicated) found steel rods/metal frames on pots reduced Australian sea lion pup entries and grey/harbour seal trapping, while four controlled studies reported reduced seal damage to salmon catches, reduced bottlenose dolphin interactions with one of two crab-pot door methods, and higher catches of undamaged salmon with wire grids and strengthened netting [2822]. Seven studies evaluated installing exclusion/escape devices on nets in the Indian Ocean/Tasman Sea and South Atlantic; two studies reported population-level outcomes with less than one-third of bottlenose dolphins exiting trawl escape hatches alive and fewer fur seal deaths with larger escape openings, and five studies (including controlled and before–after designs) found reduced entanglements of Antarctic fur seals and bottlenose dolphins, reductions on three of four vessels after device installation, and fewer fur seal entanglements after enlarging/relocating an escape panel [2823].

question_details.query: In the South Pacific and Indian Oceans, what is the best available method for shark control programs to minimize harm to non-target marine mammals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Use baited lines instead of nets for shark control. Evidence from two site-comparison studies in the Indian Ocean (South Africa) and South Pacific Ocean (Australia) found that baited lines had fewer entanglements of dolphins, whales, and dugongs than nets, and increased the survival of entangled common and bottlenose dolphins compared to nets [2856].

question_details.query: What are the potential trade-offs associated with using acoustic devices for marine mammal conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence shows acoustic devices can deter or alter marine mammal activity, but effects vary by context and species. Deterrent use around noise sources reduced harbour porpoise activity and sightings up to 1–18 km, and minke whales moved away, swam faster, and more directly when a device was deployed from a boat (2896). On vessels, bottlenose dolphins avoided boats more when devices were active; killer whales were farther from vessels during hauls with a device but distances decreased after first exposure; humpback and snubfin dolphins showed reduced surfacing, echolocation, and time spent foraging or socializing; and devices did not reduce Risso’s dolphin predation on squid catches (2815). On moorings, devices reduced numbers or activity of grey and harbour seals, harbour porpoises, and some dolphins; had no significant effect on several migration metrics of humpback whales; reduced harbour porpoise echolocation while the probability of approaching within 125 m increased over 10–11 days; and reduced seal numbers upstream of devices without reducing overall numbers (2816). At aquaculture sites, devices reduced seal/sea lion predation or approaches in some studies, while other studies found no reduction in seal predation or dolphin presence/behaviour near farms (2775). On fishing gear, devices often reduced approaches/interactions and lowered entanglements for several species, but some studies found benefits for some species or areas and not others, and others found no significant behavioural effects; devices reduced gear/catch damage in many but not all cases (2808). For renewable energy sites and cooling water intake structures, no studies were found evaluating effects on marine mammal populations (2748; 2751).

question_details.query: What is the evidence for actions aimed at mitigating pollution threats to marine mammals from agricultural and sewage sources?
What are the available strategies to reduce the negative impacts of aquaculture systems on marine mammals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Available strategies mentioned in the action documents include reducing the amount of antibiotics used in aquaculture systems (2878), introducing and enforcing water quality regulations for aquaculture systems (2876), locating aquaculture systems in areas with fast currents (2188), locating aquaculture systems in vegetated areas (2189), locating aquaculture systems in already impacted areas (2187), co‑locating aquaculture systems with other activities and infrastructures to maximise use of marine space (2079), and locating artificial reefs near aquaculture systems to act as biofilters (2196). Evidence notes: no studies were found that evaluated the effects of reducing antibiotic use on marine and freshwater mammal populations (2878), and no studies were found that evaluated the effects of introducing and enforcing water quality regulations on marine and freshwater mammal populations (2876).

question_details.query: What is the comparative evidence for the effectiveness of legislation preventing the intentional killing of mammals at aquaculture systems versus at wild fisheries?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of introducing and enforcing legislation to prevent intentional killing of mammals at aquaculture systems [2745] or at wild fisheries [2778], so there is no comparative evidence on effectiveness between these two contexts [2745; 2778].

question_details.query: What are the documented behavioral effects on marine mammals of implementing regulations for vessel operations during tourism activities?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Four studies documented behavioral effects of introducing and enforcing regulations for marine and freshwater mammal watching tours: across sites in the North Atlantic (Azores), Cananéia estuary (Brazil), South Pacific (Australia), and Bass Strait (Australia) (2838). When whale‑watching vessels followed approach regulations, fewer sperm whales and humpback whale pods changed behaviors (e.g., swimming speed, aerial displays) or avoided vessels compared to when regulations were not followed, while direction of movement and diving patterns/behaviors did not differ (2838). In the Cananéia estuary, when tour boats complied with approach regulations, fewer Guiana dolphins displayed negative behaviors such as moving away, diving, or groups separating (2838). In the Bass Strait, when boats approached a seal colony to 75 m, more seals remained on shore than when boats approached to 25 m (2838). No studies were found evaluating the effects of developing and implementing general vessel‑operation regulations around mammals (2758) or introducing permits/licences for mammal watching tours (2839).

question_details.query: What are the demonstrated benefits of prohibiting the hunting of marine mammals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across five studies, prohibiting hunting of marine mammals was associated with increased abundance in multiple species and populations: harbour seal and humpback whale numbers increased over 7–30 years after prohibitions, and 10 of 12 baleen whale populations showed significant increase rates 7–21 years after hunting bans were introduced [2780].

question_details.query: For shark control programs in Australia and South Africa, what is the evidence for alternative methods to nets that reduce harm to marine mammals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two site comparison studies—one in South Africa (Indian Ocean) and one in Australia (South Pacific)—reported that replacing shark-control nets with baited lines resulted in fewer entanglements of dolphins, whales and dugongs, and one of these studies (Australia) found increased survival of entangled common and bottlenose dolphins when baited lines were used instead of nets [2856].

question_details.query: Based on the available evidence, what are the most beneficial actions for reducing human-wildlife conflict at wild fisheries?

summary_details.relevant_summary: One randomized, controlled study in the Puntledge River (Canada) found that installing a ‘cork line’ barrier at a wild fishery did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery [2824]. One randomized, controlled study in the Puntledge River (Canada) found that switching off artificial lights on a bridge at a wild fishery did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery [2825].

question_details.query: What is the comparative effectiveness of deploying acoustic devices on fishing gear, vessels, or moorings for reducing human-wildlife conflict at wild fisheries?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across action documents, evidence on human–wildlife conflict outcomes shows: (1) Acoustic devices on fishing gear: five of six studies (including controlled and before–after designs) reported reduced damage to fish catches and/or nets by dolphins and seals, while one study found no reduction in swordfish catch damage by California sea lions [2808]. (2) Acoustic devices on vessels: one randomized, controlled study reported no reduction in predation of squid catches by Risso’s dolphins when devices of two types were used [2815]. (3) Acoustic devices on moorings: one randomized, controlled study reported a reduction in the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon [2816].

question_details.query: What is the available evidence for methods aimed at reducing marine mammal exposure to noise from industrial activities like pile driving and seismic surveys?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Three studies evaluated ‘soft start’ procedures with seismic airguns: in UK waters a greater proportion of cetaceans avoided or moved away from vessels during soft starts compared to when airguns were not firing; in the South Atlantic a pod of short-finned whales initially moved away but remained within 900 m of the vessel; in the South Pacific migrating humpback whales slowed their speed toward the vessel without significantly altering course (2897). One before-and-after, site comparison study in the North Sea found that using bubble curtains or screens during pile driving led to smaller decreases in harbour porpoise detections within 15 km compared to sites without these measures (2901). No studies were found evaluating the effects of delaying or ceasing operations when marine mammals are detected within an exclusion zone (2898), using acoustic devices at renewable energy sites (2748), reducing hammer energy during pile driving (2900), or modifying vessels to reduce noise disturbance (2904).

question_details.query: What actions are available to reduce the risk of lethal vessel collisions with large whales?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Actions identified include diverting shipping routes (2754); modifying vessels to reduce risk of physical injury to mammals (2762); setting and enforcing vessel speed limits, with two studies reporting that speed limits in key habitats were associated with fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths from collisions and fewer manatee deaths when limits were enforced system-wide (2777); using remote tools to detect mammals so vessels can alter course or speed (2757); using observers on board vessels to detect mammals and adjust course or speed (2755); using real-time automated on-board detection tools to allow course or speed changes (2756); and developing and implementing regulations for operating vessels around mammals (2758). For diverting shipping routes, modifying vessels, remote detection tools, observers on board, real-time automated tools, and regulations, no studies were found that directly evaluated their effects (2754; 2762; 2757; 2755; 2756; 2758).

question_details.query: What are the documented population-level outcomes of legally protecting marine mammals and their habitats?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Legally protecting habitat: A Mediterranean monk seal population increased over eight years after the islands it inhabited were legally protected; a bottlenose dolphin population in the North Sea was estimated to be a similar size before and after part of its range was protected; Hector’s dolphin survival rate was higher after a coastal area was legally protected than before; in the Port River estuary, a similar number of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin strandings were recorded after protection compared to before, but the number of strandings caused by humans decreased (2915).
- Legally protecting species: No studies were found that directly evaluated the population-level effects of legally protecting marine and freshwater mammal species (2923).
- Establishing networks of legally protected areas: No studies were found that directly evaluated the population-level effects of establishing a network of protected areas for marine and freshwater mammals (2913).
- Prohibiting or restricting hunting: After hunting was prohibited, abundance increased for harbour seals and humpback whales over 7–30 years in multiple regions; numbers of mature male sperm whales did not differ significantly before or 31 years after prohibition; a review reported significant increase rates for 10 of 12 baleen whale populations during 7–21 years after legislation to prohibit hunting (2780).
- Ceasing or prohibiting disturbing activities in sensitive areas: Harbour porpoise activity increased at a stony reef after fishing was prohibited and the reef was restored with boulders (2917).

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and negative outcomes associated with captive rearing and rehabilitation of marine mammals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Hand-rearing orphaned or abandoned young has yielded documented post-release survival in individual gray whale, Steller sea lion, and bottlenose dolphin calves over monitoring periods of days to months, with approximately three-quarters of released Antillean manatees and two-thirds of Florida manatees known to survive at least one year; some captive-reared manatees reproduced, and survival of released Pacific harbour seal pups was similar to wild pups, though some captive-reared individuals died before or after release, were returned to captivity, or survived only with supplemental feeding, and released harbour seal pups travelled greater distances and farther from the release site than wild pups [2926]. Rehabilitating and releasing injured, sick, or weak marine mammals resulted in 10–100% survival during monitoring periods ranging from three days to five years across multiple species and locations, with more than a quarter of rehabilitated Hawaiian monk seals reproducing; behaviour of some rehabilitated harbour porpoises and harbour seals was similar to wild animals, but at least a quarter of California sea lions treated for toxic algae poisoning died or were euthanized and released individuals showed altered movements, reduced time diving or hauled out, and shorter, shallower dives compared to wild conspecifics [2925]. Rescuing and releasing stranded or trapped marine mammals yielded 17–100% survival over three weeks to three years in multiple dolphin, whale, and seal species, with reproduction documented in a rescued bottlenose dolphin and more than a quarter of Hawaiian monk seals surviving and reproducing when rescue/release was combined with at least seven other survival-enhancing interventions [2924]. Releasing captive-bred manatees led to survival of two of three Antillean manatees and two of 14 Florida manatees for at least one year without further intervention [2933]. No studies were found evaluating outcomes of rehabilitating and releasing marine mammals following oil spills [2871].
